sentences.text: Some people say the whole society is happiest when individuals pursue their own happiness.
Others say individuals are happiest when they sacrifice their own happiness for the happiness of the whole society.
Which of these ideas is true?
When a 'conflict' occurs, people try to reach an 'agreement'.
This allows people with different ideas to live together and pursue their own happiness at the same time.
When they do this, they must ask 'What is the greatest good to society?' and 'Can everyone participate in reaching an agreement'.
They use concepts such as 'efficiency' and 'fairness' to evaluate decisions and the decision-making process.
People all want to be happy, so they must cooperate in creating a 'public space' that makes this possible.
We must learn to live in the public space, keeping in mind both the interests of 'personal happiness' and 'the happiness of the whole society'.
In order to do this, we need to think about who we are, and what society is.
Who are we? We are adolescents.
The word 'adolescence' comes from Latin and means 'to grow up'.
The psychologist G.S. Hall described adolescence as a time of 'storm and stress'.
Our bodies and minds grow rapidly, and our environment changes.
This can make our feelings unstable.
Adolescence is a time of 'psychological weaning'.
This is a time when we become independent from our parents.
It is also a time of 'marginal man'.
This means we are no longer children, but we are not yet adults.
During this time, we try to find out who we are. This is called 'identity'.
The psychologist Erikson said that finding our identity is the most important task of adolescence.
The psychologist Erikson called adolescence a 'moratorium'.
This means a time when we do not have adult responsibilities.
In the past, this time was very short.
People became adults at a young age.
Now, the moratorium is getting longer because society is more complex.
We need more time to learn the skills we need to be adults.
The law was changed in April 2022. People come of age at eighteen instead of twenty.
However, the age of legal responsibility is not always the same.
At 14 years: You can be punished for a crime.
At 15 years: You complete compulsory education and you can be employed.
At 18 years: You are recognized as an adult, can get married, and can vote.
Acceleration in human development and early sexual maturity has resulted in adolescence beginning at an increasingly young age.
The question is whether this is accompanied by psychological maturity.
Psychological changes in adolescence are seen when we begin to experience romantic and sexual desires, together with a sense of self-awareness.
Self-awareness makes us distance ourselves from our parents and establish ourselves as individuals with attitudes, values, and patterns of behavior that are different from our parents.
This gives us the desire to make our own decisions and drives us to resent the restrictions placed on us by parents, teachers, and other systems of established authority.

2-2.title: The Rebellious Phases and Adolescent Crisis

sentences.text: This is an assertiveness that first appears in infancy as the first rebellious phase and appears again in adolescence as the second rebellious phase.
These are the first steps we take in becoming independent of our parents and other figures of authority in our lives.
This part of our lives is often referred to as the stage of adolescent crisis when we can be in danger of losing sight of ourselves.
Adolescence can be an opportunity to break free of childhood and create a new identity.
Some adolescents don't appear to go through a time of crisis, which is called a stable adolescence.
However, many adolescents are easily hurt and experience emotional instability, swings in emotion, loneliness, anxiety, and feelings of inferiority.
It is normal to have serious worries about our bodies, personalities, academic studies, friends, and the opposite sex.
Worrying can be a sign of strong sensitivity, and overcoming these worries helps develop strength of character.
Having a trusted person to talk to can be very helpful, and high school is a time when you may find a life-long friend.
Adolescence is when we learn adaptive behaviors that enable us to cope with worries and control our emotions.
Things will not always go as you wish, and you may experience frustration and conflict.
In these times, we often resort to defense mechanisms, which are ways we deal with emotional problems to avoid getting hurt.
These mechanisms, such as repression, rationalization, and sublimation, help us overcome failures and disappointments.
